text: HIV does not replicate in naive <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells stimulated with CD3 / <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In this report , we demonstrate that the T cell tropic strain of HIV , LAI , does not replicate in naive <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells stimulated by cross-linking CD3 and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
In contrast , LAI replicates well in memory <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells stimulated in the same way .
Unlike this physiologically relevant stimulation , <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulates productive LAI replication in both naive and memory T cells .

These studies were conducted with highly purified ( FACS-isolated ) subsets of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells identified by expression of both <extra_id_0> CD45RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CD62L <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Remixing of purified T cells showed that naive T cells do not suppress LAI replication in memory T cells and that memory T cells do not restore LAI expression in naive T cells .

The suppression of productive LAI replication in naive T cells is not due to differential expression of viral coreceptors , nor is it due to inhibition of activation of the important HIV transcription factors , nuclear factor-kappaB and activator protein - 1 .

The inherent resistance of naive T cells to productive HIV infection , coupled with their proliferative advantage as demonstrated here , provides a sound basis for proposed clinical therapies using ex vivo expansion and reinfusion of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells from HIV-infected adults .
